DataElement.preferredDefinition: The name of the cardiac activity that produces an effect, or that is intended to alter the course of a disease in a patient or population.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A hollow organ located slightly to the left of the middle portion of the chest. It is composed of muscle and it is divided by a septum into two sides: the right side which receives de-oxygenated blood from the body and the left side which sends newly oxygenated blood to the body. Each side is composed of two chambers: the atrium (receiving blood) and ventricle (ejecting blood)._An activity that produces an effect, or that is intended to alter the course of a disease in a patient or population. This is a general term that encompasses the medical, social, behavioral, and environmental acts that can have preventive, therapeutic, or palliative effects.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A hollow muscular organ which receives the blood from the veins and propels it into the arteries. It is divided by a musculomembranous septum into two halves -- right or venous and left or arterial -- each of which consists of a receiving chamber (atrium) and an ejecting chamber (ventricle). SYN cor, coeur.

Concepts.definition: A hollow organ located slightly to the left of the middle portion of the chest. It is composed of muscle and it is divided by a septum into two sides: the right side which receives de-oxygenated blood from the body and the left side which sends newly oxygenated blood to the body. Each side is composed of two chambers: the atrium (receiving blood) and ventricle (ejecting blood).

Property.preferredDefinition: A particular course of action intended to achieve a result.

Concepts.definition: An activity that produces an effect, or that is intended to alter the course of a disease in a patient or population. This is a general term that encompasses the medical, social, behavioral, and environmental acts that can have preventive, therapeutic, or palliative effects.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: evaluations of the patient and the patient's disease.

DataElementConcept.origin: MCL:Molecular and Cellular Characterization of Screened Lesions
DataElementConcept.changeDescription: 3/14/22 jk UCSF ISPY-2 AI, released as part of quarterly content review and prior reviews with SMEs5-20-19 tt created for Breast systemic therapy module.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: The words or language units by which a thing is known.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Radionuclide Ventriculogram Scan Left Ventricular Ejection Fraction

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Radionuclide Ventriculogram Scan Left Ventricular Ejection Fraction
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A multi-gated acquisition (MUGA) scan and a form of radionuclide imaging that provides a comprehensive look at blood flow and the function of the lower chambers of the heart ventricles.: The fraction of the left ventricular end diastolic volume ejected with each beat. The left ventricular ejection fraction is equal to the left ventricular stroke volume divided by the left ventricular end diastolic volume.

Concepts.definition: A diagnostic test used to evaluate the pumping function of the heart's ventricles. A radioactive tracer is injected into a vein and a gamma camera detects the radiation released by the tracer, with image acquisition triggered (gated) at different points of the cardiac cycle.

The fraction of the left ventricular end diastolic volume ejected with each beat. The left ventricular ejection fraction is equal to the left ventricular stroke volume divided by the left ventricular end diastolic volume.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An image of the heart produced by ultrasonography.: The fraction of the left ventricular end diastolic volume ejected with each beat. The left ventricular ejection fraction is equal to the left ventricular stroke volume divided by the left ventricular end diastolic volume.

Concepts.definition: An image of the heart produced by ultrasonography.

The fraction of the left ventricular end diastolic volume ejected with each beat. The left ventricular ejection fraction is equal to the left ventricular stroke volume divided by the left ventricular end diastolic volume.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: evaluations of the patient and the patient's disease.
